Returning to School: Reminders for parents and families

It is critically important that parents and families do their part to slow the spread of COVID-19. This role for parents and families includes:

Limiting potential exposure to COVID-19 by social distancing, wearing masks, and avoiding large crowds. Watching for potential symptoms and staying home when sick. Getting tested when appropriate and staying home while waiting for test results.

While all are eager to return back to school and connect with others in our school community, staff, students, and families need to follow guidance about when they should NOT be in school. If you are sick, stay home and consider COVID-19 testing. If you have had close contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19 in your home or in other activities, stay out of school for the full 14 days of quarantine.

By staying home when you are sick or have been exposed to a positive case, you are helping your community stay in school together.

The Invention of Wings by Sue Monk Kidd
Cane River by Lalita Tademy
Brown Girl Dreaming by Jacqueline Woodson
The Twelve Tribes of Hattie by Ayana Mathias
The Kitchen House and Glory Over Everything by Kathleen Grissom
The Nickel Boys and The Underground Railroad by Colson Whitehead
Homegoing by Yaa Gyasi
Beloved by Toni Morrison
The Dry Grass of August by Anna Jean Mayhew
Washington Black by Esi Edugyan

Temporary food benefit available to Minnesota families with children who would have received free or reduced meals if schools were open.

Families who received free or reduced-price school meals in 19-20 school year or attended a school that offers free school meals to all students - but were NOT receiving SNAP or MFIP benefits on March 18- MUST complete an online application at mn.p-ebt.org between June 8, 2020 and June 30, 2020.

Eligible children will receive a one-time payment of $325 per child on an existing active EBT card or a newly requested P-BEBT card to help fill the gap created by a loss of school meals.

Families that were receiving SNAP/EBT on or before March 18,2020 received an automatic payment on their Minnesota EBT card on May 30, 2020.

In the spring of 1959, a North Mankato Jr. High teacher wrapped this flag in a newspaper and placed it on top of a cabinet. It soon fell and rested behind the cabinet through the years. It remained through the Vietnam, Persian Gulf, 9-11, and Iran-Iraq conflict eras. In 2015, during the remodel of the old Garfield Elementary to the now Bridges Elementary, the flag was found. The newspaper was dated from the year I was born, and now, over 60 years later this unique 48-star flag can fly proudly again to honor all our soldiers, veterans, all emergency services personnel, healthcare workers, essential workers, and their families.

‚ÄúAlone, we can do so little; together we can do so much‚Äù - Helen Keller

-Head Custodian of Bridges Community School James Meagher

A joint team of students from East and West recently completed the NASA WEAR Challenge. NASA challenged students to design a piece of wearable technology that can protect astronauts heads and eyes from excessive radiation during solar particle events. Water is one of the best protective materials for this type of radiation so students creatively focused their design on using Orbeezs, water containing gel spheres, as the primary protective layer.

Students just completed the initial proposal stage of the competition and submitted the design concept you see in the photos below. The top five teams from across the United States will be selected to build their prototype and then travel to Langley Research Center in Virginia to share their finished product with NASA engineers. Advancing teams will be announced on March 20th! #NASA_WEAR #NASARadworks #Kato_WEAR
